episode.title: County Court of Ulster County v. Allen

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in County Court of Ulster against Allen.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Ms. Shapiro?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes sir.
This habeas corpus proceeding presents two issues.

The first issue is waiver and the second is the constitutionality of the New York State evidentiary presumption, which provides with certain exceptions, that presence in an automobile of any of the weapons enumerated in the statute is presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the automobile at the time that the weapon is found.

The threshold question here is whether respondents have preserved the question of the statute’s constitutionality or habeas corpus review, considering that respondents failed to object at trail to a jury instruction, which only partially explained the statute and again failed to object either at trail or on their state appeals to the constitutionality of the statute itself.
A consideration of both the facts of this case and the applicable law compelled to finding that respondents have indeed failed to preserve any substitutive constitutional claim for collateral review.
The facts in this case are not in dispute.

The respondents and a 16 year-old girl, who was later adjudicated as a youthful offender, and was therein after referred to as Jane Doe, were riding in a car on the New York State Thruway in upstate Ulster County, when they were stopped for speeding through work zone.
The driver, respondent Lemmons, produced a license and a registration.
A radio check was made and it was determined that he was wanted on a Michigan fugitive warrant.
He was arrested.

One of the policemen, one trooper Askew returned to the vehicle, looked in through the right front passenger window and detected protruding from a ladies handbag, Jane Doe’s handbag, on the floor of the front seat of the car, a .45 automatic pistol.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is it clear that it was Jane Doe's handbag?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, it is clear, there is no dispute.

He reached in, removed that gun, which turned out to be fully loaded, I believe with modified hollow point bullets and found underneath that gun a second gun, a .38 Smith & Wesson revolver, also fully loaded.
The officer placed all three of the remaining occupants of the car under arrest and then attempted to enter the trunk of the car.

The trunk key was not recovered on any of the respondents, it was not in the car and so when the car was returned to the barracks, the trunk was pried open and the police found therein a pound-and-a-half of heroin and a .45 caliber spitfire machine gun, also loaded with 27 rounds of ammunition.
All four of the passengers were indicted on three counts of felonious weapons possession and one count of narcotics possession, a charge which in New York at that time bore a potential life sentence.
They -- as the record clearly shows, all the parties, the respondents and Jane Doe noted a cooperative defense although they were individually represented by counsel.

In particular, respondents directed their aspect of the defense toward rebutting the articles in the trunk of the car, the heroin count and the machine gun count and Doe’s counsel Mr. Goldberg, who parenthetically is representing respondents in this proceeding, directed his attention toward the handguns in the car.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I thought that Jane Doe was tried in a juvenile proceeding of some kind?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No, she was tried jointly.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As a co-defendant in this proceeding?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: As a co-defendant and it was not until sentencing that the trial judge set aside her conviction, adjudicated her a youthful offender.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So there were four co-defendants in this case?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Absolutely, yes.

At the course of the people’s case, the respondents and Jane Doe made a routine pro forma motion to dismiss, which in New York is rarely granted as jeopardy may often attach, should the motion be erroneously granted and then on appeal it cannot be reversed.

The respondents’ motion in particular was directed toward the fact that as the handguns were in Jane Doe’s handbag, they were on her person under the meaning of the statutory presumption at issue and thus they could not be held responsible.

The trial court agreeing with the District’s attorney found that the location of the guns, since they were not actually in Jane Doe’s pocket or whatever, was presented in fact of the jury and thus he denied their motion.

In fact, respondents Hardrick and Allen even appear to concede in that motion, which is reproduced on page 17 of the Appendix, then in fact, the judge may have been right that it is a question of fact.
At the close of the entire case all counsels adjoined in moving to dismiss the machine gun and heroin charges against Jane Doe.
In other words, Jane Doe’s lawyer made the motion and counsel for the three respondents piped up and said, yes Your Honor, we think you ought to grant Jane Doe’s motion.

At summation, Doe’s lawyer placed great emphasis on the large caliber of the handguns, the weight of the guns, which amount to approximately 6 pounds, the size of the guns and in particular the position of the guns in the handbag, they were positioned crosswise so as to keep the handbag open.

To support his position that the respondents tossed the guns in the bag at the time that the car -- either at the time the car was flagged down by the police or in the interval when the driver was being arrested.

Respondents Allen and Hardrick on the other hand placed great emphasis on the absent trunk key and the fact that the car had been borrowed that very morning from respondent Lemmon’s brother in Rochester, New York, approximately 250 miles away from the site of the arrest.
And then in unmistakable language in their submission, these respondents Allen and Hardrick virtually conceded their guilt on the handgun charges.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They conceded what?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: They are guilt on the handgun charges.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In the arguments, you are telling us.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In their final arguments?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: In their submission and I have the quote from the submission, which --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The page you are referring to on the appendix is?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Page 21 to 22, which also appears on page 654 of the transcript.
This is what Mr. Toraka, counsel for Allen and Hardrick said to the jury.

If you are living under their times and conditions and you travel from a big city, Detroit, to a bigger city, New York City, it is not unusual for people to carry guns, small-arms to protect themselves, is it?

There are places in New York City policemen fear to go, which you have got to understand you are sitting here as jurors, these are people live flesh and blood the same as you, different motives, different objectives.
And he went on to say that small arms were in the pocket-book, it is true, the question is who do they belong to?

If you think that Hardrick and Allen had exercised dominion control over the weapons in the purse and follow the law as the judge gives it to you on the presumption of what was in the purse as to all 4 or 3 or 2 or 1 and I think that this cannot be mistaken as anything other than a concession on those charges.
After summations the Judge charged the juror --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I may be dumb today, but I do not understand why that is a concession?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You have to explain a little more to me, why is that a concession, I do not know, there is a concession that they were in the car?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No, it is concession that they, Allen and Hardrick brought the guns from Detroit where they were coming from to take to New York City.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I meant the part what you read, you say it is on page 17 of the appendix?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No, I am sorry.
21 and 22 of the appendix.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, I am sorry.
I misunderstood you.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, the guns were concededly found in the car?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the car was on a trip from Detroit to New York City, that is, he conceded no more than that, did he?
Then they acknowledged facts?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: I believe he conceded more than that.
He said, look at these two fellows, they are going to New York City where they are afraid of crime and they are bringing these guns with them, what is wrong with that?
But he did not say, why are you charging me or Allen and Hardrick with the pistol charges, when Jane Doe had the guns in her bag and they are really Jane Doe’s guns.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if you look on 22, he made that point, but I notice had denied it?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, he is surely on 22 (a), it is in the fifth and sixth lines, fourth, fifth and sixth lines, sounds as though he is waiving any question about the validity of the statute, where he says, if you think that Hardrick and Allen exercised dominion control over the weapons in the purse, then follow of the law as the judge gives it to you on the presumption of what was in the purse is as to all four or three or two or one.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: It would seem to me at the very least --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think that was his failure to make objection?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yeah, I certainly do, I certainly feel that at the very least that quotation indicates that —

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That would perhaps explain why he did not object to the instructions?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: I have some theories in that regard as to why, I think that he may not have objected or why none of the respondents did object to the presumption?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Because in theory Ms. Shapiro, I do not know what the procedural practice is in New York, but if a trial judge tells you after you have objected that I am going to charge on the presumption, you do not go to the jury and tell them that this presumption is all bad and the judge may tell you, it is alright, but I do not believe that.
You follow the law as the judge gives it to the jury in your argument of the jury; you are bound pretty much by the judges’ variation of the law.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Absolutely, but at this point, the jury had not yet been charged.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He was anticipating that.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: He was anticipating charge and you would think anticipating the charge, he would also be anticipating the full charge, since he was quite aware that beyond the person presumption was included in the statute and his early motion indicated to some degree that he felt that his defendants were entitled to that charge.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, of course, Mr. Justice Rehnquist is entirely correct that the lawyer in his summation cannot argue is what the judge is later going to say in the charge, cannot properly do so without being guilty of some misconduct.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: I would not think that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It would appear here that he was reading the statute just as the prosecution was reading it, when you couple that with the fact that he made no objection to the charge.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, I would think so.
And he certainly made no constitutional objection even in the earlier motion to dismiss and --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now the Court of Appeals’ opinion in the habeas case, Second Circuit opinion does cite passages from briefs but as I read Judge Jason’s opinion for the majority of the New York Court of Appeals that does not pass on any constitutional question, does it?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: What Judge Jason appeared to do or what it seemed apparent is that he did not view a constitutional question as having properly been raised and I think that if you read the full text respondents’ briefs 2 or 3 quotes, they were essentially the same brief and it is repeated throughout the joint appendix, I think you will see that, Your Honor will see that what -- the claim they were making essentially is that not that the statute was unconstitutional but that the failure to grant them the benefit of the exception was the unconstitutional aspect and clearly they had waived that by their earlier failure to object to the charge.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But why was there ever exhaustion of the statement remidies here?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you contend that there was no exhaustion of statement remedies here?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: We contended that early in the habeas proceedings, the state did contend it, but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But have you abandoned that claim now?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: It appears that the waiver, which we argue would bar collateral review in this Court, would bar collateral review in the state court in the state habeas corpus proceeding as well.
The only state remedy open to him.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yeah, but this question was never presented in the state courts?
Has the Federal’s habeas statute been satisfied?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, I think there is a question at this stage in proceeding to require the respondents to go back through a state habeas proceeding, considering that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that one of the questions you have raised here?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No, I have not Your Honor.
I have not raised exhaustion, you know in my petition of the certiorari, none of the questions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is the state in position to waive that, this federal statutory requirement, may a state waive that?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: The Second Circuit does not seem to think so but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: We are not waiving it.
I think what I do -- I view it as in this case a futile exercise and I do not think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is a futile exercise?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: To ask these respondents to return and go through a state habeas proceeding, since their state direct appeal is completed.
The only method, the only state procedure they could pursue would be a state habeas.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How do you know what the Court of Appeals would decide on this question if it was never presented to them?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: On the facial constitutionality statute?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On the direct appeal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On the direct appeal.
If you say if the Court of Appeals of the State of New York did not pass on this question, if it was never presented to them, how do you know how they would decide it?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: I do not know how they would decide Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then what do you mean it is a futile exercise to go back to the state courts?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: It is our point that in effect they waived their right and the state court to even raise the constitutionality of the presumption.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are you saying that not having raised it on direct review, your state courts would not entertain it on state habeas.
Is that what you are telling us?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then why should we entertain it here, that is the next question?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: That is the point, it goes around in a circle.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Alright but in answer to just my brothers White and Brennan you pointed out, you do not raise the exhaustion point here because of the well-settled rule that exhaustion is satisfied if there can be a showing that a further pursuit of the question of the state courts would be futile.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes, that is true, that is our position.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that still does not answer the question of the direct appeal and your claim that it was not even presented in the direct appeal and that therefore the New York Court of Appeals was not asked to rule on the constitutional questions.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Well, what I think the New York courts did is that they found that the respondents by failing to object to the charge, which in that case incorrectly embodied the statutory presumption, has thereafter any waived any claims flowing from that failure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you suggesting to me that, maybe you are quite right that the person who is convicted in a state trial court can completely abandon his appeal in the state system and come directly into Federal habeas?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No Your Honor.
I have never said that at all but once -- you cannot appeal through the state system, a claim that you have not presented at the trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright, so let us assume a person is convicted in a New York trial court, he just does not appeal and then he goes to state habeas, he will be thrown out.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, he will.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can he then come to this Federal habeas?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, why is not that this case?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: He has waived his state direct appeal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So in this case, what about this particular question in about the facial constitutionality of this presumption if – let us assume it was never presented to the Court of Appeals of New York, although it could have been and it was not and it was not decided by them and it may not be available in state habeas, but is it available in Federal habeas?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Wasn't that this case?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: No, what the New York – what I believe the New York Court of Appeals did and of course the opinion is subject to some interpretation is that it held that having waived the objection to the jury charge, which was the embodiment of the statutory presumption, the respondents waived all claims flowing from that waiver including the facial claim, he has applied claim and the state will claim.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that is now [Indiscernible]

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Yes.
Respondents -- I have just discussed the New York Court of Appeals’ opinion.
I would like to say that at no stage in the federal or state proceedings, did the respondents give a reason for their failure to object.
In fact, it is not until their brief to this Court that they suggest for the first time that the reason might be inadvertence.
However, I would like to say that far being inadvertence, the record below lies in inadvertence.

The record shows that the respondents knew the presumption would be charged, expected it to be charged, that they had a specific strategy and the specific strategy they had was to deflect pressure away from Jane Doe on the handgun charges, so that Jane Doe, a 16-year-old with no prior record and everything to gain and virtually nothing to lose would not testify against them and that is indeed what happened.

The respondents give their entire defense away from putting pressure on Jane Doe, away from pointing an accusatory finger at Jane Doe and in fact the part of Allen and Hardrick’s charge that I quoted to to the Court indicates that they were virtually conceding those counts rather than have Jane Doe testify on the serious life sentence charge.

And I say this also because it seems unlikely that counsel, who had so successfully defended these respondents on the drug charge; this was actually by any standard a very successful defense, would have been unlikely, particularly since they knew about everything that was going to happen at the jury charge period, would be unlikely to overlook such an important feature.

And there is also possibly another explanation for this waiver, which may come to mind and that is that these respondents were in a sense willing to accept a compromise verdict to allow the jury to convict them on the lesser charges in the hopes of getting an acquittal on their life sentence charge.

And of course, respondents have a burden for coming forward with a good cause, mere inadvertence does not satisfy the Wainwright v. Sykes standard, but if either of the theories that I have proposed to the Court is supported by the record and I believe they are, these respondents have failed to even meet the Fay v. Noia standard.
If notwithstanding the respondents’ waiver, the court nevertheless considers the constitutionality of the presumption, the state submits the statute as constitutional.
The statute is a carefully drafted statute, which embodies legislative recognition that illegal handguns and automobiles are closely linked with the commission of violent crimes.
The presumption provides that presence in a private automobile an illegal weapon is presumptive evidence of its possession by all the occupants of the car unless one of the exceptions applies.

There are three exceptions; there is the on the person exception, which this case involves, there is an exception where possession will not be imputed to a taxi cab driver, if a gun is found in the car and the third exception is if one of the occupants of the car not present under duress has a valid license.
There are also approximately 15 exemptions, which are contained in another statute 265.20 of the penal law.
And persons -- these exemptions are the persons, who voluntarily surrender handguns for example, or manufacturers, shippers, other legitimate firearms’ holders or owners.

The elements of the car and the felonious weapons possession, which respondents state quite accurately in their petition for the habeas corpus in paragraphs five and six, is a knowing and voluntary possession.
The requisite metal state must be proved by evidence independent of the presumption.
Moreover, New York has a very liberal definition of constructive possession.
The weapons must be within the immediate control and reach of the accused and where it is available for his unlawful use if he so desires.

So thus once the requisite mental state of knowing involuntary possession is established through other evidence, the presumption simply permits, a jury can infer an individual and close proximity to weapon, has that weapon within his immediate reach and control, thus it merely of course the evidence, its natural prohibitive force in effect.
In this case -- in such a case rather, the relationship between the proved fact and the presumed fact is so close that it must satisfy any test this Court deems appropriate.
And I referred to the beyond the reasonable doubt test, which is really not that different from the (Inaudible) test.

Finally, the statute focuses on narrowly defined conduct, presence in a private automobile, as the case has showed the presumption is applied in a principle way by the New York courts, on a case-by-case basis taking every variable into consideration.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it New York is one of those states that purports to say that if the presumption disappears and you just disregard it, when any contrary evidence suddenly comes up?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: Not, when any contrary evidence.
If there was contrary evidence for example that was compelling, the New York judge certainly need not either send the case to the jury or charge the jury on the presumption.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So apparently, he thought that there was not enough evidence, but he did instruct on the presumption?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: He did instruct on the presumption, he omitted the instruction on the exception.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think he told the jury that they could ignore the presumption if they wanted to?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: There in the charge, the judge does say specifically and I do not have the exact page here that you may disregard -- court says, you may find for the respondent even though he submits no evidence in rebuttal.
And then of course, he went through a very careful reasonable doubt charge and said but --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But did he not virtually give the instruction that is given on the possession of recently stolen property that you may infer?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: And the warrant exceptions.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: On what page is it?

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: 23 (a) Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I knew I had seen it somewhere, but essentially the possession of recently stolen property instructs.

turn.speaker: eileen_f_shapiro
turn.label: Ms. Eileen F. Shapiro
turn.text: It says the burden rest upon the shoulders of the people, it never shifts.
The defendant is never called to establish his innocence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white

turn.text: No, I would cite to the fact that respondents raised the constitutional issue and that since the Court of Appeals did not expressly address it, but did say that they felt that this presumption was valid --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where was it that they said that?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Alright, on pages --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I got to get quote at some place.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: 41 -- 43 through 45.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Counsel, if you take a look at the top of page 51a and see if that helps you.
Is that the dissenting opinion?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes, I believe that is Your Honor.
Yes, that is Judge Walker’s dissenting opinion in which he says that constitutional challenges have been rejected in the past by the New York Court of Appeals.
The Judge Walker felt that this presumption was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And that suggests that the issue is before the Court, perhaps?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, it definitely --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, it really suggests that the dissenters talk something about it.
It does not suggest that the court thought it was there.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, it does suggest that the issue was before the court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was before the court in people against Terra, like in [Inaudible] New York.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: But since Judge Walker found it unconstitutional here in this case Your Honor, referring back to Terra, he was clearly saying that it is an issue here too.

But getting back to the point that I was initially making with you Your Honor, Justice Rehnquist, even though the court did not spell out, even though the New York Court of Appeals did not spell out or converse, what their position was on the constitutional issue, that does not mean that we are precluded from Federal habeas corpus proceedings.
All we have to do is exhaust our remedies in the state court.
We only have to raise the issue.
If the Court of Appeals refuses to confront it, that is not our fault and that does not preclude us under 2254 from raising that issue thereafter in the federal courts.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if it is an established rule of New York practice that you must make a motion based on a constitutional claim at the time that judge charges the jury.
You do not, you make it at the time you made it, in this case, the same procedural history up to the New York Court of Appeals.
You argued the question in the New York Court of Appeal, the majority opinion simply does not mention that one.
Do you think you can go into Federal Habeas on that?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Alright, Your Honor, again you phrase that in terms of this being a charge case.

Even if the judge, in this case had made no mention whatsoever of this presumption, even if he had never told the jury that they can convict on the basis of this presumption, respondents would still be entitled to the relief, which they have been granted.
That is so because the state in this case rested their case without any actual proof of the crime charged.
Instead they relied solely on this presumption.
I would like to refer Your Honor to the colloquy that occurred at the end of the state’s case on exactly that.
The defense counsel had argued that the presumption wasn't valid in this case; admittedly they did not raise a constitutional claim at that point.
What is important is that they argued that it was not valid.
And in response, the court turned to the prosecutor and said referring to defense counsel’s argument, he is saying that the only proof you have again is your presumption, right?
The prosecutor - correct.
The court - The defender was in the car and the statute presumes you have no other proof.
The prosecutor - Correct.
So this is a case in which there simply was no proof and defendants right, their constitutional right attached at that point.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is the prosecutor saying correct with respect to the contention, the court’s paraphrase of the defense contention or correct to the court's statement that that is the prosecution’s position?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, I think the last comment by the court makes that clear.
He says, you have no other proof, asking question, there is the question mark after that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What page you are on?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Oh, I am sorry, page 15a, bottom of 14a, the last three lines of 14a and the first three lines of 15a.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That does not mean that anybody says there was a proof just means there is no more proofs than the fact the gun and the defendant were both in the same car?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: That is right and that is why --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That does not mean there is no proof?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, it does that the presumption --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All you are arguing is that you should not be able to infer possession from the presence of the gun and the defendant in the car at the same time?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: That is right Your Honor.
And if you can't constitutionally do that, then the prosecution’s case necessarily falls at that point.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, suppose the judge had said, all the evidence you have is that the gun was in the defendant’s hand in the car, is that all you had?
He says, correct.
Would that be alright?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, then they would not be relying on the presumption.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Right, but here they have admitted that they were relying solely on the presumption.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: [Inaudible] when Constitution questions on one sentence and one word by judge everybody else, only one word I know is [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, that is what the judge I think should have said, in this case, at this point.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Any other word, [Inaudible] did not they?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: I am sorry, I do not quite understand.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, may be I do not know, I do not understand what you are talking about?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: What I am saying is that the defendants’ due process rights were violated at the point that the state rested its case without presenting any actual proof of possession but instead relying solely on this presumption.

So if this presumption is unconstitutional, defendants’ rights were violated at that point no matter what the judge thereafter charged the jury, even if the judge had charged the jury that they could not convict on the basis of the presumption.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Young, the colloquy you referred to of course was in connection to the motion to dismiss the indictment, is that right?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: That is right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And is it correct that defendant though testified?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Oh, you caught me totally unawares, it is long since long as I read the transcript, I am not sure, I do not think any of the defendants --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The dissenting opinion is what puzzles me and as Mr. Justice Powell pointed out early, it refers to the fact that the defendant Doe was the only woman in the vehicle expressly admitted that it was her possession?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: I think a police officer testified that she had made that admission Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, so there was other evidence then beside there was evidence about [Voice Overlap]

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Only evidence of Doe's possession and Doe was not a respondent here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand but there was some moral testimony about what happened at the time that the vehicle was stopped?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well essentially all --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So there was something more in the record other than the fact that the guns were in the car.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: No that was essentially it, as to these – as to the respondents --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you just told me a moment ago that police officer testified that she made some remarks concerning the location of the gun.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Oh you mean that it is a bad evidence, yes that does not apply to the respondents, it only applies to Jane Doe.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would you mind reading me again what the judge asked?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes, the court referring to the argument defense counsel had just made, he is saying that the only proof you have again is your presumption, right?
[Inaudible] and the prosecutor - Correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well then that [Inaudible] it was all the evidence?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes, that is all the evidence that they have.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they had a lot more evidence than that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: All the evidence they relied on that [Voice Overlap] dismiss the indictment.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, his next comment is the court - The defendant was in the car and the statute presumes, you have no other proof?
And the prosecutor - Yes, that is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well we can look at the whole record and see what that means because it is ambiguous and it can't mean literally what it says because on this record, it is clear that these two, one an automatic and one a pistol 45 and a 38 and were in plain sight sticking out of the handbag.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: In plain sight to the police officer, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, then you mean they were not in plain sight to the driver.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: No, because they were in between the right front seat and the right front car door, next to which Jane Doe was sitting, so between the seat and Jane Doe, they were totally out of sight of everybody else in the car.
There is no testimony to the effect that anybody else in that car could have seen those guns and logically they could not have seen them because they were all the way over there.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You concede the officer could see it but you are saying that the jury could not reasonably infer that anyone in that car could see it?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, number one I do not thing that, that is a reason to inference, but number two, sight is not all that is required for possession, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I am just taking one segment of it.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There is other evidence besides what this colloquy the judge indicated.
The evidence is that they were in plain sight in the handbag in the car.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Right, one gun was totally out of sight because the police officer did not even see it until he had removed the first gun.
The first gun was in sight only in that the handle was sticking out of the top of the purse that was located in that location.
I think it would be a pretty strange --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The only point I am making is that is evidence from which a reasonable juror could reasonably conclude that other passengers in the car saw the same thing the officer did.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: As to the bottom gun?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: As to the gun which was in plain sight.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Alright, but they were convicted of both guns.
So even if sight alone was enough to convict here, it would not justify the conviction on the second gun.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is the crime greater for the possession of two guns than one?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, the presumption was used to convict for both.

So, obviously the issue would be raised as to the second gun even if Your Honor were correct in saying the mere -- that the first gun was visible and moreover to visibility permitted a conviction simply because it was visible.
Now we strongly disagree with that.
We do not think that visibility, that even if the gun was visible to the other passengers, that is enough.
It simply strained the imagination to say that simply because the gun was visible that all of the people in the car automatically possessed it because it was visible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the presumption does not mean everybody automatically possessed that.
The presumption as I understand it means that the jury may look at that presumption with the rest of the evidence and may draw the inference that everyone possessed it, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: No Your Honor, the reason I know is visibility, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: But let us look at exactly what the presumption --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They do not have to accept the presumption?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Alright, no they do not, but let us look at what the presumption means because it does not mean what Ms. Shapiro described to you.

New York Court of Appeals has uniformly held that this presumption authorizes a jury, if they so wish in most instances to infer possession of a gun to anyone who is present in the car where that gun is found.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If they conclude that they have come back with a guilty verdict, they would have violated their instructions unless they have found that beyond a reasonable doubt, every member in the car possessed the gun?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well that is not –

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The presumption, well, they have been told to find the defendant guilty unless they find the status prove the case beyond a reasonable doubt.
And may be the presumption under the so called inference is part of the truth, but they nevertheless have to be convinced.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well then Your Honor, let us look at page 25 of the joint appendix which contains the part of the judge’s charge addressing the presumption and there his lead of statement is our penal law also provides that the presence in an automobile of any handgun or firearm which is loaded is presumptive evidence of their unlawful possession.
So that alone could be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but the jury nevertheless, it's presumptive evidence that is true, but nevertheless it has to be evidence that will convince the jury beyond a reasonable doubt, that is the instruction.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well, according to the New York Court of Appeals and I think this Court is bound by the New York Court of Appeals’ interpretation of the statute, New York Court of Appeals states in their opinion in this very case that the presumption creates a prima facial case against the defendant.
Now, it is my understanding --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know that just means it is enough to get to the jury.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: That is right, enough to convict on.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but the jury – yeah, but the jury nevertheless has to be convinced beyond a reasonable doubt, that is the way it was instructed and say, find the defendant guilty, without finding guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, they have violated their instructions.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes but based on --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright, but whatever the evidence is, it has to convince them beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: And the judge was telling them that they could reach their conclusion based only on this presumption.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but they don’t suggest it, they did not have to.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: No, they did not have to.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they have to find him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
Now you cannot construe the constructions any other way, can you?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes, I can well, I can construe those together.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If you had, why do not you come up here and claim that some other section of the Constitution has been violated, that they have violated the beyond reasonable doubt standard?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well to a certain extent, this does because it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that does not – that isn't the question you presented to us?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: I know because we do not feel that, that is the central issue here.

What we feel as a central issue is that the due process rights were violated because the jurors were instructed that they could draw an irrational inference and as this Court had said in every presumption case it has dealt with, that is enough to violate the defendants’ rights.
You do not have to also violate the rights by mis-instructing them as to the reasonable doubt standard.

In every one of the presumption cases where this Court has reversed the conviction because the presumption was irrational, the juries were charged that they had to find guilt beyond a reasonable doubt in those cases.
So it is not enough that they were instructed on reasonable doubt in this case.
What is important is that the prosecutor rested this case solely on the basis --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So are you really objecting to on a Sixth Amendment basis that they really interfered with your right to a jury trial?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: There are implications of that Your Honor.
It is more a due process violation under Leary.
What the judge has said is the jury does not have to be rational.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You want us to affirm the –

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you want us to affirm the judgment in this case?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Yes, I do Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then what you are arguing about?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Well I --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You have not cross petitioned?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You have not cross petitioned.
You have done all these things that were not before the Court and I am not here, am I right?

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: No, all the issues that we are talking about now were before the Court.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And decided maybe --

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Pardon

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Go ahead, go ahead.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: I am sorry, I misunderstood Your Honor’s question.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think your time is up counsel.

turn.speaker: michael_young
turn.label: Mr. Michael Young
turn.text: Alright, thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The case is submitted.
